title: Cloud phishing campaign abuses Google Cloud email feature
executive_summary: Attackers used the Google Cloud Application Integration email feature to send phishing emails from a legitimate domain.
By abusing trusted infrastructure, the campaign bypassed common email security defenses and targeted thousands of recipients.
what_happened: Cybersecurity researchers identified a multi-stage phishing campaign abusing Google Cloud Application Integration's Send Email task feature to send phishing messages from a valid Google domain.
Threat actors configured emails to resemble routine notifications (e.g., voicemail alerts or document access requests), increasing the likelihood of users trusting them.
Approximately 9,394 phishing emails were sent to around 3,200 organizations over a two-week period observed in December 2025.
Clicking the embedded links led victims through genuine Google storage redirection and fake CAPTCHA pages before landing on credential-harvesting login pages.
who_is_affected: Employees who receive legitimate-looking enterprise notifications
Organizations in U.S., Asia-Pacific, Europe, Canada, and Latin America
Sectors relying on Google automation workflows such as manufacturing, tech, finance, and services.
attack_flow: Abuse of Google Cloud Application Integration to send phishing email
Email delivered from a legitimate flask domain (noreply-application-integration@google.com)
User clicks link → redirected via Google Cloud storage
business_impact: Increased risk of secondary attacks (account takeover, lateral movement)
risk_reason: Using trusted cloud infrastructure reduces detection likelihood by security filters and increases user trust, making email-based phishing more effective.
what_usually_goes_wrong: Users trust emails from well-known domains
Email filters unable to distinguish legitimate automation from abuse
Lack of additional email security checks beyond DMARC/SPF

immediate: Warn users about suspicious emails even if from trusted domains
short_term: Enable advanced email filtering with behavioral analysis
Implement MFA to reduce credential theft impact
long_term: Train employees on cloud-based phishing tactics

what_this_does_not_mean: Google Cloud infrastructure is fundamentally insecure
All emails from trusted domains are malicious

signs: Unusual email volumes from automation tasks
Unexpected sign-in attempts after phishing events
alerts: New device login from foreign location
